								my hands hurt.i mean, i'm not even particularly good - sure, i have some records with the barracuda but i'm not a zen-level enough pilot to pop it open normally. nevertheless i've spent hours chasing hundredths of a second on the leaderboards. i powered through each season of the campaign, learning just how i needed to dart around each corner to keep up. i've restarted a million times at the first imperfection, frustrated by my own inconsistency. and the process has not been kind to my hands.and it's all totally worth it.if you're at all a wipeout fan in any capacity - whether you're a middling player like me, a venom class pilot that likes to casually race, or a literal zen-level deity with a neGcon - install this game. it's still perhaps rough around the edges in some places, but don't let that or the early access tag keep you away. there's a ton of AG goodness in this package.the visuals (and the physics) hearken back to the days of the PS1 - the game looks like 2097/XL, feels like 3, and has a wealth of tools for for the intrepid modder. custom ships are already supported (with custom tracks forthcoming) if you know your way around a 3D model, and steam workshop support is, i believe, in the works.online play isn't in yet, but don't let that stop you either. the leaderboard competition is stiff as it is, so you can still show off your skill and sate your competitive appetite. and besides, it'll be great practice for when the online mode does release.best of all, the devs are wipeout-heads, so you can guarantee that the game will stay true to the spirit and even the aesthetic of the wipeout series.so grab a controller and come put your hands through the wringer. you'll be grateful you did.

								EN : Extremely faithful to the original PS1 Wipeout games, BNG is a game by the fans for the fans.Physics are well handled, the game feel is identical to the one you could have had when playing Wipeout XL/2097/Wip3out.Demanding, requiring learning various piloting techniques, the game offers a steep learning curve, yet allowing newcomers to get in. Taking the form of speed classes, you'll find a growing game speed, from slow to blinding fast. Just don't expect to master Zen Class in 10 minutes!Visuals will be the most dividing part. Here, the goal is to emulate the PS1 look, and various options are there to replicate visual glitches typical of the old console. To me, the game has a charming feel to it, as you can still feel the modern technology below the retro-appearance.Learning and perfecting your piloting will be the main driving force in the game, which, as an early access game does already have its fair share of content.AI races and tournaments, Time Trials (where competition for the top leaderboard spots is tight!), an incoming multiplayer (both online and splitscreen) all with 8 original ships, 5 bonus ships, and their dragship versions (insanely fast but very hard to steer) on around 15 tracks (more incomming too!)To conclude, BNG offers a very interesting feature. Customisation. You can import the orginal 3 Wipeout ships if you own the discs/ISOs. All of them, with corresponding stats! Steam Workshop is supported, and you could very well make your own ship, if you know how to model. Sounds effects and music are also customizable.The dev team is working hard on the game, they are very open to feedback of their players, which is quite nice. I do think BNG has a bright future!I recommend this game to all lovers of the original Wipeout series, all lovers of demanding yet rewarding gameplay and all lovers of the PS1 era.FR : Extrêmment fidèle aux WipEouts de l'ère Playstation 1, BNG est un jeu par les fans pour les fans.La physique est maîtrisé, le feeling manette en mains est identique à celui qu'on a pu avoir en jouant à Wipeout 2097/Wip3out.Exigeant, demandant une assimilation de techniques de pilotage variées,le jeu propose tout de même une courbe de progression adaptée à tout les niveaux. Présenté sous formes de classes, vous y trouverez une vitesse croissante, du plus lent au plus rapide. Ne vous attendez juste pas à piloter parfaitement en Classe Zen dès les 10 premières minutes!Les visuels sont l'aspect qui partagera probablement le plus. Le parti pris ici est d'émuler le look des jeux PS1, et diverses options permettent de simuler les défauts d'affichage de cette vieille console! Le jeu a, pour ma part, un charme fou, car on sent quand même la pointe de modernité, sous l'apparence retro.Apprendre et perfectionner son pilotage est le facteur le plus motivant du jeu, qui, fort de son statut d'early access, ne rougit pas devant la quantité de contenu déjà disponible.Des courses/tournoi contre l'IA, des contre-la-montre (ou la conquête des leaderboards est serrée!), un multijoueur en approche, le tout avec 8 vaisseaux originaux, 5 vaisseaux bonus, et les version dragship (super rapide et bien plus difficile a jouer) ainsi qu'une quinzaine de circuits. Pour finir, BNG propose une customisation très intéressante. Vous pouvez importer les vaisseaux originaux des 3 premiers Wipeout, si vous possedez les cd/isos. Les vaisseaux sont tous la! Et avec des stats correspondant aux originaux. Il propose également un support workshop, et donc il est tout a fait possible d'importer vos modèles, si vous savez les fabriquer. Enfin, les bruitages et la musique sont aussi interchangeable.Le jeu est suivi de très prêt par son équipe de développement, très ouverte à l'écoute et au feedback de ses joueurs, ce qui est fort appréciable. Il a des beaux jours devant lui!Je le recommande a tout amoureux de la saga originelle, tout amateur de gameplay exigeant mais très jouissif une fois maîtrisé, ou tout simplement, tout amateur de l'ère PS1.

								What a fantastic thing!  BallisticNG GETS future racing: the exhilarating speed, the trance-inducing electronic score, and a delicious aesthetic that rides the line between elevated and industrial. BallisticNG is still a work-in-progress right now, so there are some usability issues that crop up: navigating the game's menu via a controller is a rather haphazard affair (up and down did not work on my controller's joystick), the racetrack selection screen would really benefit from a visual preview of the track you are selecting, and the tutorial needs an overhaul (put that beautiful pilot guide in the game!).  Even so, the work that remains seems paltry in comparison with what has already been accomplished - the game is a joy to play, it runs well, and it's full of beautiful little touches, such as custom cockpits for every racecraft, that really emphasize how much love and care has gone into this game.  Were BallisticNG a futuristic racecraft, consider me thoroughly strapped in and along for the ride.

								Ballistic NG is quite the breath of fresh air in a world of poorly developed gamed either made free with the intention of conning people from their money or made to cost about 10 dollars wiht the intention havingf them play long enough to screw them over on their Steam refund if it tu8rns out to be crap.So, do I recommend this game? Yes, certainly. And here's why."I present to you.... HI-HO SILVAH! AWAAAAAAAY!"The first and rathewr important part of this game is that it's completely FREE. no subscriptions, no microtransactions, 100% free. IT's very reminiscent of WipEout according to my friends, in fact, the trailer itself explicitly says it pays HOMAGE to the first 3 WipEout games. Lastly, the nicest thing I see here, is that the "Why Early Access?" bubble actually looks rather self-critical than like it's trying to promote itself as being built by the community and not actually listening. The developer behind this game is constantly updating. Something most unheard of from titles like Starbound from Chucklefish, Robocraft from Freejam, or Killing Floor 2, from TWI. Each of which having committed their own series of offenses."So... What's in the bag?"A look without touching the game shows it goes all the way back to the original Play Station's graphical fidelity. I personally like it, but the people who are crazy for graphical quality might get turned off. Needless to say, don't let it turn you away. After all, it's completely free, and the developers intend to keep it that way.The controlds feel slick and smooth and respond nicely, although it's better with a controller in some cases. I've played using both a controller and a keyboard for the first campaign section as far as I could go, and they both feel very responsive. My only complaint is that the controls could still use some minor improvements from how they currently are, but nothing truly too severe.The frame rate is quite silky smooth, even with my obsolete hardware here, and I can vouch that it'll run fine on a toaster. Since it only needs about 183 Megabytes of space on a 64-bit Windows 7 computer, it doesn't take up much space, which is a fantastic detail to note.[n]"GRAPHICS!"[/b]There's quite a few options, but nothing to increase texture quality. While that is a bit of a let-down, there's nothing to really worry about in that regard. The rest makes up for it.Draw Distance going from 30 to 144 is quite nice, and the only other games I've seen with a draw distance function are Minecraft and Firefall, but we don't talk about Firefall any more. The horror... Anyway...FXAA filtering. Very nice.Bloom - A nice little addition as well.Camera damage - For those of you who like to immerse yourselves.And even more that you can mess around with in your gameplay settings for your HUD and some other little functions. Sweet, right?Resolutions also go from the old CRT-grade 640x480 all the way to your typical 1080 pixel resolution quality at 1600x900, a very nice variety. With this kind of game, 4K resolution isn't all that necessary. So yeah. Some nice functions in this game to buff up the quality."IS it still fast and furious like the last games...."Yes. Yes it is. It feels just as fast as it should be, which is awesome. However, as you ascend hills, the speed can slow to a frantic sprint at times. Not quite as fast as a super sonic craft going up a hill, frankly. That said... The gameplay is amazing. You have, so far, 7 different power-ups you can grab during the race: Cannon, Plasma, Missile, Rocket, Mines, Auto-pilot and Shield.In addition to this, you have a large variety of ships for a title like this. There's easily more than 10 to choose from, including another whole column of ships you can unlock. And that's not yet mentioning the Ship Importer, which I'll get to later in this review. And each of these craft have their own unique stats, so there are plenty of ways to play this game.And yes, you can still destroy other racers as you make your rounds about each track. But be careful, the same will happen to you, and you only progress to the next race upon reaching First Place. As the game is now, it's not too much of a challenge to achieve in the first Campaign section, but I don't know about the other two yet.Another cool feature is online mode. Try it. Tell me what it's like, because my internet is just barely better than a 56K modem at the moment. It... Kind of sucks. *hangs head in shame*There's three "Campaign" sections, and I haven't beaten even one of them yet as I've been busy with other titles. That said, if you don't feel like unlocking everything the old fashioned way, then you can go to the profile tab in the main menu of the game and go to "Unlock Everything" to... Yup, you guesssed it: UNLOCK EVERYTHING, but this disables achievements, so beware."YOU CAN MOD!?"Yup. You can put in custom tracks, vehicles and music into the game, which is pretty freaking awesome, but at the moment, the feature isn't functional. I'm assuming it'll come out at a later time. So since this game is of such upstanding quality at the time I found it? ESPECIALLY for an Early Access title? This feature will get a free pass from me since the entire thing is free and I'll review it when it's out and there's tracks and vehicles to try out.It WILL have Steam Workshop support, I believe, so hang in there, folks."YOU GOT ANYTHING TO SAY NOW!?"Now, for the lingering issues I feel. Sometimes the game will chug a bit on my crapper toaster here, but with my kidn of crap computing power, that's to be expected. There isn't much you can do with a Mobility Radeon HD 4250 when it doesn't even reach a full 256 Megabytes of VRAM (It only has 252.6... x_x), but for what this product presents, its a nice blast to the past.Some of the power-ups can feels a bit dumb, and some can actually be WAY too powerful, but each is balanced enough to function as they are.... All of them except Auto-Pilot. If you activate Auto-Pilot and pass by an armed contender when you're alreadyb low on energy, you won't be able to dodge as he blasts you into a smoldering black heap of metal debris on the track. Not too exciting there."Final Verdict?"I'ds give this game an 8.6 out of 10. IT feels good, the sound, game, environment, everything looks very nice. There's only a few things missing, and a few other things that could really use some tweaking, but beyond that? This is serious quality for low gaphical fidelity. A pleasant breath of fresh air in 2016 when games have stagnated for 5 years straight now.Give it a whirl. I think you'll definitely enjoy this game if you enjoy racing games.

								**Low playtime on Steam Build, but I've put at least 20 Hours into builds 0.3_2 & 0.4**I've been hopelessly addicted to Ballistic NG for the last week or so. I'm always on the lookout for good anti-grav racing titles. A lot have disappointed me in the past, as I couldn't help but hold each of them up to the same standard as the WipEout games. Ballistic NG changes that - it's cut from the very same cloth as XL and WipEout 3. It FEELS like WipEout 4.The controls are perfect - if you've played any of the first 3 WipEout games, then you'll be able to jump straight in, no problems. It's THAT spot-on. Even the behaviour of the camera is identical, and this contributes a lot to the game's authentic WipEout feel.Graphically, it's a PSX game with modern touches, and that's fine with me. A lot of hard work has gone into re-creating this style, and it pays off in spades. It also means the game is incredibly scalable - the game runs near flawlessly on my Razer Blade 14 2013 edition.I really can't say enough good things about the sound. It\'s WipEout - Von Snake & Friends have done an amazing job creating a soundtrack worthy of it's heritage, with nods to the most classic songs in WipEout history. They're genuinely great tunes, not pale imitations. The custom sound support is the icing on the cake. Early Access Review
								QUICK SUMMARY:This is essentially a clone, for nostalgia and for hardcore fans as well as newbies who are interested, of the original 3 psx WipEout titles (WipEout, WipEout 2097, Wip3out). If the game feels "dated" or "old school", you know why.SERIOUS TIME! WHAT IS BNG?The closest thing you will EVER get, at this moment, to a recreation of the physics of WipEout on PSX.Plays wonderfully and the learning curve is STEEP esecially for beginners. I highly recommend trying Practice mode with the three prototype tracks and different vehicles. That'll get you in the grove and will teach you cornering. Not too much content yet but these guys are working their asses off hardcore on this thing and having impeccable gameplay and good AI that feels nostalgic is just ♥♥♥♥ing amazing.PROS- the physics are almost, ALMOST perfect. More notes on that below.- The AI is defaulted to easiest and has a nice natural feel to get you into the groove.- The stages feel great and each stage gets crazier, a very nice comfortable learning curve especially for hardcores.- The ships feel varied, just like the psx wipeout titles- Music is good. Overall style feels nostalgic. c:CONS- Very VERY hardcore. There doesn't appear to be much of an "incredibly easy, for the sake of learning" track, like that of Talon's Reach in WipEout 2097 on the PSX.- For people unfamiliar with the WipEout games, the controls are incredibly technical and steep. The first campaign speed class could use some slowing down for the newbies.- Wall collisions are really tight, tighter than on PSX, in terms of "feel", in my opinion.- On long winded turns, AI sometimes drops 3 mines dead center at once that are almost impossible to avoid, ruining a race and crushing health. Maybe there could be a way to prevent close AI from earning the same items and ruining a strong laptime.- Sometimes (very rarely) ship clips through walls on some tracks. It's to my understanding that y'all are gonna work out those kinks. c:EXPLANATION OF PHYSICSOkay, so, this game, following on the formula of the PSX wipeouts (most notably WO3) has some very unique wall collisions.Essentially, as long as your nose is relatively parallel to the track wall, you will grind against the wall without hitting it or taking damage so long as you're on track. Once you're more than say 20 or so  degrees off with your craft's nose, BANG, you lose all your speed. Just like the oldies.The airbrakes will slowly shift your nose and also cause your ship a loss of traction. This has an advantage: in holding both brakes you get to slide your nose, ahead of time, into corners, at the cost of a lot of speed.Airbrake and nose control (you press up and down to keep your ship balanced for jumps and hills) is very necessary to master the game, especially past the first set of stages in campaign.** On this note, I would like to say that I think there should be more leeway on the degree to which your nose can be parallel to the wall, and how far into the wall you can fly, before the game determines a collide. The room for error feels quite a bit steeper than in PSX wipeout; right now it's somewhere between original WO1 (no wall grinding) and WO3 (loose wall grinding), and the psx games greatly favored the back ends of the ship for grinding to accomodate your ship sliding through turns. I would definitely give this game some tweaking.My method of turning corners consists of two to three steps, try and practice this, it is unique to BNG:1) Turn in the direction of the next turn while punching that side's airbrake to quickly shift your nose parallel to where the turn looks like it's gonna leave you off. (If it's a 45 degree turn, hard punch that airbrake till your craft rotates about 45 degrees)2) While still turning in that direction, quickly release the airbrake and HOLD DOWN THE OPPOSING AIRBRAKE. Holding down the airbrake that OPPOSES the direction of your turn basically removes all traction from your ship and causes a slide3) If you're entering too fast, punch down both brakes instead of the opposing brake. It's better to lose most of your speed than to punch a wall. Walls drastically hinder your acceleration.Cheers, and happy playing!

This game sets out to be an imitation, and succeeds very well at capturing the look and feel of the original entries in the series.MechanicsThe mechanics feel closer to the subject matter than any other imitation I've played. Controller detection and integration is also intuitive.GraphicsGraphically, the look of the game is a solid rendition of the original games. I think this is a brilliant move, as it sets the graphical fidelity for the game at a reasonably obtainable level of detail, while successfully achieving the look that they set out to attain. The game looks better in action than in the screenshots shown, especially at max settings and with V-SYNC enabled, and are nostalgic. They even included PS1 era vertices. SoundWipeout is known for its music selection, and again the choices made here faithfully reproduce the music styles of the 1990s that were featured in the Wipeout series.ConclusionIf you're a fan of Wipeout, or other anti-gravity racers like the seminal F-Zero, then I recommend trying this game.

I think this is a brilliant move, as it sets the graphical fidelity for the game at a reasonably obtainable level of detail, while successfully achieving the look that they set out to attain. The game looks better in action than in the screenshots shown, especially at max settings and with V-SYNC enabled, and are nostalgic. They even included PS1 era vertices. SoundWipeout is known for its music selection, and again the choices made here faithfully reproduce the music styles of the 1990s that were featured in the Wipeout series.ConclusionIf you're a fan of Wipeout, or other anti-gravity racers like the seminal F-Zero, then I recommend trying this game.

Early Access Review
								BallisticNG is still in Early Access as I write this, my opinion may change as the game develops.BallisticNG is a futuristic racing game which uses anti-gravity ships darting around the track. If this sounds familiar you'd be right. The game is heavily 'inspired' by the original 3 Wipeout games on PS1/PS2/PC. I say 'inspired' because it couldn't be much more obvious.While it obviously can't use the same ship names and so on due to copyright, the game tries to mimic Wipeout as close as it can. The ship designs are new but look like they'd fit right in the PSX games. The way the ships handle feels almost exactly like 2097 did. You steer not only with the regular steering but also with the ship's airbrakes (a concept which will be familiar to anyone who's played either Wipeout or F-Zero). Pulling one airbrake makes the ship veer in that direction, which can be used to 'drift' a corner or slingshot your ship around it. Pulling both slams on the anchors and is really useful for the tightest corners. You can also pitch the nose of the ship up or down to land big jumps better and lose less speed.The tracks share the same kind of futuristic/neon aesthetic as the old games and range from very simple to extremely difficult. The visual style is very low poly and is done deliberately to look more like the old Wipeout games. Most tracks (not all) have a pit lane which will extend your lap time (as it's a longer diversion) but will restore your shields. On the subject of shields, each craft has one of varying strength. The craft are balanced so a fast ship that handles well will generally either have terrible weapons or low shields. A tanky ship with good speed and weapons would typically have awful handling. They all feel noticably different and you'll need to experiment to see which fits your playstyle.Normal gameplay sees you advance through several cups, which consist of multiple races. Finish as best position as you can and don't get eliminated. Each track features weapons pickups you can use to try and eliminate other ships from the race. These range from offensive weapons (rockets, missiles, cannon, plasma) to other miscellanous pickups (shield, which makes you invulnerable to damage for a few seconds) and autopilot (the AI takes over your ship control for a few seconds, great for hard parts of a track!).There's also time trials, free play, survival mode and the game will even soon have online multiplayer. When you consider that all this is free it's amazing.As if that wasn't enough, if you own Wipeout or Wipeout 2097 you can insert the disc and import the ships from it!If I had to pick things to improve...the collision detection can sometimes feel a bit off and one or two tracks probably need adjusting (one track has a corner which you sometimes get stuck on because it goes against gravity and your ship struggles to make it). The in-race UI isn't great; something as important as your race position shouldn't be a small font out of your main field of view. All in all though these are very minor complaints and I would definitely recommend anyone who was a fan of the old Wipeout games to pick this up. It's free, what do you have to lose?

								This review was assembled when BallisticNG was at v0.4.BallisticNG is the closest thing there is to a modern recreation of the classic WipEout games on the original PlayStation back before the end of the 20th century, primarily Wip3out. The level of commitment to this era is very significant, with the low-poly models, low-res textures and limited (but changeable) draw distance deliberately echoing the graphical fidelity of this golden era of home console gaming.Despite the intentional limitations, the game currently plays like a dream for anyone who ever played WipEout back in the day. The keyboard controls are surprisingly good considering the need to manage steering, pitch control and airbrakes, sometimes all at the same time. The track selection is rather generous given WipEout's tendency to not have that many tracks within any singular game (with the exceptions of Pure and Pulse including DLC). The craft selection is also pretty well done and there's even a selection of unlockable bonus ships to fly in.The ability for the game to get custom tracks and ships only makes the deal that much better. This combats the biggest weakness of the actual WipEout games in that, despite being fantastically fun to play, they did ultimately lack in content such as tracks. The planned Multiplayer is the icing on the proverbial cake, it just needs to wait for everything else to come together in due time.I'm very much looking forward to seeing how BallisticNG shapes up over the coming months, and so should anyone who enjoys the re-emerging futuristic racer genre.

 Summary	Updated as of v0.6A really fun tribute to the early days of WipEout on the ps1. It's a little rough around the edges, sure, but if you enjoyed those old WipEout games - or even the new ones, like me - this game absolutely deserves your attention. Perhaps I just have a very specific taste in racing games (actually, I definitely do), but this is my favourite racer since WipEout HD. Good things	 Fast, hover-y racing mechanics. I never played the old WipEouts, so I can't comment on closeness of simulation - but it feels really great to fly these ships. Amazing throwback to PS1 graphics, with some modern quality-of-life improvements, such as HD resolution and bloom lighting. Really great soundtrack that sometimes sounds 'Tron Legacy'ish and sometimes left me thinking "This HAS to be from WipEout, it's too authentic!" Mod support! If you can model and texture a ship, you can fly it! Scraping the walls makes the most satisfying metal-on-metal sound ever. Things that could be improved  Some the feedback to getting hit (and particularly being eliminated) lacks 'oomph'. Some of the tracks are bit erratic and hard to navigate. 0.6 update: The redesigned tracks are much more manageable for a learning player, and look amazing as well! Sometimes, I fly through walls/the terrain. 0.6 update: Much less common in this update. Lack of campaign/obvious ways of tracking my progress beating tracks. Wipeout HD style campaign now included!Note that a couple of the tracks in the latest update are undecorated, but hey - it's free and otherwise works really well.

								InShort : Intense heart-stopping and immensely rewarding gameplay....if you're willing to put up with possibly the worst UI design I've ever seen on anything.  Highly recommended.I'd recommend anyone seeking a thrill to give this a shot. The kick you can get out of this game is insane, feels like riding an extreme roller-coaster the entire time. And there's a lotta content out there to keep you occupied for a while. Also, did I mention there's workshop support for some rather sick community content with custom ships n' tracks? Sweet!All I'd request from you when if you try it is a little bit of patience with the game's other minor annoyances. For one, the UI is downright pathethic. Doesn't respond to clicks half the time, and has W mapped to select and LShift mapped to back in the Menu. I mean, only a sadist would come with crap like that. And even the default control scheme is counter-intuitive (on keyboard atleast). But once you do get past those small niggles, my, you could sink hours into this one wiithout even realizing it. Just get used to it, and it'll be nothing less than an edge-of-your-seat joyride after that. Good work, devs!Updates -1. I see some negative reviews complaining about the pod control feeling 'off'. There's a chance you may be right, but I'd suggest you try remapping the controls to my control scheme, as I feel that the poor defaults may be the real reason than the game itself. I'd request you to give it a shot, as there's truly a gem hidden underneath to b found here :)Thrust - UPTurning - LEFT and RIGHTPitch - W and SAir Brakes - A and DBoost - LShiftUse Powerup - SpaceDrop Powerup - QAbove controls are inspired by the defaults of one of my favourite indie titles called Distance. I think this scheme works great for high-speed stunt-boost-p'up fueled racers like this one.2. There're some odd technical hitches in a couple of areas here and there that tends to break the flow, but not enough to put me off game. I noticed random half-second long freezes occuring mid-race that really hurts at times. Sounds - The game has great music and environment sounds. The announcer, especially, sounds awesome. But the pod sounds seem to lack that 'whirr and rumble' that I wanted to hear from it. Early Access Review
								As a huge fan of the Wipeout series, this is actually a very good game. It's very faithful to the original three, older Wipeout games (let's not beat around the bush, this is pretty much a clone with a different name). The gameplay is really tight and the controls are great, and never feel awkward. The track designs are good, though some are better than others. Aesthetically it's not as good as Wipeout though I doubt anyone can come close to the Designers Republic, however it still looks nice. The music is also good and fitting of the style and atmosphere, although slightly forgettable. Though apparently you can add in your own music, but I haven't tried this yet.What I really like is that you get the same sense of speed and thrill as in the classic Wipeout games, and it rarely feels cheap when you fail. On the flipside, it's also very satisfying when you get good at it. The race ships you choose from also have a lot of individuality and variation in both looks and stats which is great.There are a few glitches and bugs, though not hugely noticeable and mostly rare. Once or twice I've appeared to clip through a wall or floor and fall out of the level, and also at times the walls/floors of the tracks appear to vibrate slightly. Also, the graphics aren't the greatest, being somewhere between PS1 and PS2 level. However to be fair this is a (free!) early access game and it's otherwise very solid and complete so I'm not complaining too much.Overall if you're a fan of racers or especially Wipeout then definitely give this a shot. It's not like it'll hurt your bank balance, since it's free! I'd happily have paid a few quid for something of this quality.

Early Access Review
								I've never played a WipEout game.So when I opened this up I didn't know at all what to expect. And for the first while... I was impressed. Though I always felt I was average at racing games, BaNG has proven to be a dastardly and difficult game that even my old reflexes couldn't keep up with at all. I had to start from the bottom. I had to relearn everything I thought I knew about racing. And it was fun.But as time went on, and I finally got over some minor bumps, and actually became able to beat some of the campaign missions, it started to occur to me that something very... important was missing from this game.This isn't WipEout.This may seem  like an obvious thing to say- well of COURSE it isn't WipEout, that franchise is dead. But that's not what I mean.What this is, and what it is doomed to be no matter how good it is, is a clone. A knockoff. A two-bit copy.G-Tek is the obvious parallel to FEISAR, though FEISAR's aspect of purism has been forked to Tenrai. Omnicom (could have been more subtle there) and Diavolt are obvious Auricom and Qirex expies. So on, so forth. The menu and general design of the game feels decidedly cheap, a far cry from the stylized and aesthetically pleasing work The Designer's Republic did on the old WipEout games (which were one of my main points of interest in the series, though I never got to play it), and making it feel more like it was made by people who only vaguely remember what they're copying.The music is also sub-par: Listening to the original WipEout/2097/Wip3out soundtracks I found a significantly higher variety of music styles than you'd find in this game. It's too techno. Too early 2000s. And trying WAY too hard to sound like what they thought WipEout sounded like. And after a while it gets incredibly grating. (The saving grace is you can replace it with better music, though I still haven't figured out how that works. But that should be able to augment the soundtrack, not fix it.)In general, as a pundit, I guess I could be pleased with this game. But WipEout fans shouldn't be looking here. They'll NEVER escape the fact that this is NOT WipEout and it will NEVER be WipEout and it lacks a lot of, at least to me, what made WipEout interesting.WipEout fans should go buy a PS1 already.ED: To those talking about how "it'll get better, it's early access, blah blah blah," remember that these are my thoughts of the game as it stands right now. I do have the power to edit this, and as things change you might see the big red thumbs down at the top of this become a blue thumbs up.As a TL;DR : This game has excellent physics, and is easily one of the most challenging racing games I've ever played. However, it suffers problems with identity, as it still feels like a clone and thereby carries all the stigmas that a clone must carry. The music is♥♥♥♥♥♥♥too.
